content: The "Boutique Fuels Reduction Act of 2004" allows for temporary waivers during supply emergencies. Section 211(c)(4)(C) of the Clean Air Act is amended to allow the Administrator to temporarily waive fuel or fuel additive regulations in cases of extreme supply circumstances after consultation with the Secretary of Energy. The Clean Air Act allows the Administrator to grant a temporary waiver for extreme fuel supply circumstances, such as natural disasters or equipment failures, if it is in the public interest and cannot be compensated for otherwise. The Clean Air Act allows the Administrator to grant a temporary waiver for extreme fuel supply circumstances, such as natural disasters or equipment failures, if it is in the public interest and cannot be compensated for otherwise. The waiver must be limited to the smallest necessary geographic area, effective for 20 days or shorter if deemed sufficient, and include a transitional period for wholesalers and retailers to adjust their inventory. The Boutique Fuels Reduction Act of 2004 allows the Administrator to grant a waiver for extreme fuel supply circumstances, with specific conditions for implementation and public notice requirements. The term 'motor fuel distribution system' will be defined by the Administrator through rulemaking, and regulations must be promulgated within 180 days of the Act's enactment. This Act does not limit other waiver authorities of the Administrator. The Administrator can grant waivers for extreme fuel supply circumstances under the Boutique Fuels Reduction Act of 2004, with specific conditions and public notice requirements. This Act does not limit other waiver authorities of the Administrator. SEC. 3. CAP ON NUMBER OF BOUTIQUE FUELS. Section 211(c)(4)(C) of the Clean Air Act is amended to restrict the approval of new fuels in State implementation plans, with exceptions for certain criteria. The Clean Air Act restricts the approval of new fuels in State implementation plans, with exceptions for certain criteria such as replacing existing fuels without increasing the total number of approved fuels. States can still require the use of registered fuel additives. SEC. 4. STUDY AND REPORT TO CONGRESS ON BOUTIQUE FUELS. The Administrator of the EPA and the Secretary of Energy will conduct a study on the impact of State plan provisions on air quality, fuel blends, availability, fungibility, and costs. The focus is on developing a Federal fuels system to maximize motor fuel supply, preserve air quality, and reduce price volatility caused by boutique fuels. Recommendations for legislative changes will be made to Congress based on the study findings. The Administrator of the EPA and the Secretary of Energy will conduct a study on boutique fuels to avoid duplication of effort. They will coordinate with affected parties for comments on air quality impact assessment and fuel availability, blends, fungibility, and costs. A report with recommended regulatory and legislative changes will be submitted to Congress within 12 months. The House Energy and Commerce Committee and the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee will be involved in the study on boutique fuels to address air quality impact assessment, fuel availability, blends, fungibility, and costs. A report with recommendations for regulatory and legislative changes will be submitted to Congress within 12 months. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The term "Administrator" refers to the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, and the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Energy.
